abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project was
            marginally unsatisfactory. Most of the project objectives
            were not met; however, several benefits were attained, such
            as enterprise financing; progress of legal and regulatory
            frameworks, through the preparation, and passing of major
            legal texts, including the commercial code. Additionally,
            private sector development institutions, banks and financial
            institutions in particular, benefited from training and
            capacity building activities. Despite the substantial work
            initiated under the project, most was not implemented, such
            as the expected development of private sector activities.
            Macroeconomic imbalances increased during implementation,
            posing high risk and uncertainties, which hindered private
            investment development. The key lessons suggest that
            extended caution should be taken for private sector
            development operations to succeed, particularly where
            political uncertainties persist. Thus in an environment
            unlikely to combat inflation through fiscal discipline,
            creditworthiness is not sustainable. These high risk factors
            require a monitoring and evaluation system, critical to a
            successful project supervision. Furthermore, public/private
            sector partnerships are unlikely to succeed if controlled by
            public entities, with poor knowledge of the private sector
            needs. An overall management coordination would prevent
            institutional problems, and foster implementation.

18156684.theme: Other financial and private sector development,Legal institutions for a market economy,Administrative and civil service reform

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's main objective is to
            promote growth by supporting the establishment of an
            incentive framework for export-oriented private sector
            investment.  The project consists of a line of credit for
            productive investments, support to industrial
            infrastructure, improvements in the business environment and
            in financial intermediation, and technical assistance in
            support of private sector development.  Eligible projects to
            be included under the line of credit (subproject investment
            financing) include : i) investment projects in all
            productive sectors, with particular emphasis on
            export-oriented manufacturing, small-scale mining, and
            agro-industrial projects; and ii) modernization of
            equipment.  An additional US$3.5 million will be used for an
            investment program in sites and services in the undeveloped
            industrial zone of Bujumbura, the capital city.  There will
            also be a technical assistance component which will be
            passed on as a grant by the government to implementing
            institutions.  The grant will be given to : a) participating
            intermediaries; b) private entrepreneurs; c) the Central
            Bank and banks to implement staff training and capacity
            building programs, to improve banking supervision, economic
            and monetary analyses as well as credit evaluation; d)
            Ministry of Commerce and Industry for a Policy Coordinating
            Unit (PCU); and e) Ministry of Energy and Mining to assist
            in reforming mining investment and regulatory policies.
